entry.title: Re: Accelerating Financial Close: Integrating SAP Datasphere with SAP Group Reporting
entry.content:
Hi Brian,

You‚Äôve identified the exact bottleneck: forcing SAP S/4HANA to calculate rules during extraction is resource-intensive. The SAP Datasphere approach solves this by shifting the "heavy lifting". Instead of extracting pre-calculated results, we move the raw base data to SAP Datasphere and apply the reporting logic within its modeling layer. This offloads the runtime calculations from S/4HANA to SAP Datasphere‚Äôs high-performance engine, keeping your core system fast while delivering the governed results SAP Group Reporting needs.

Bernd

entry.title: Introducing Our Next EGI: Joule Prerequisites and Activation
entry.content:
Program Overview: 

This 3-day implementation program equips your team with the knowledge and hands-on experience needed to successfully deploy SAP‚Äôs AI-powered digital assistant, Joule. Through expert-led sessions and guided configuration exercises, participants will navigate the complex technical architecture and complete critical pre-requisites for a production ready Joule implementation. 

 

What You‚Äôll Achieve 

 

Day 1 ‚Äì Foundation and Architecture 

Gain a comprehensive understanding of Joule‚Äôs architecture and the Business Technology Platform (BTP) ecosystem. You will explore how critical components ‚Äì Cloud Identity Services (CIS), Build Work Zone (BWZ), BTP and Line-of-Business solutions ‚Äì interconnect to power Joule‚Äôs capabilities. Through live demonstrations and hands-on exercises, participants will navigate BTP account structures, understand entitlements and subscriptions, and validate system prerequisites. By the end of day one, you will have assessed your organisations readiness and begun to configure your dedicated Joule environment. 

On a BTP account we will have a live demo after integration with SuccessFactors 

 Hands On 

Translate theory into action. Guided by our experts, you will step into your own BTP environment to assess your landscape, confirm sub-accounts, validate key subscriptions and officially designate your primary Joule subaccount.  

 

Day 2 ‚Äì Integration and Activation 

Build on foundational knowledge with deep-dive sessions into identity management and user provisioning. Learn how Cloud Identity Systems integrates with your corporate Identity Provider and enables secure authentication for Joule. Configure Build Work Zone to serve as the unified interface where Joule delivers AI-powered insights across your SAP landscape. Participants will complete provisioning tasks, establish trust relationships between systems and expose content from your chosen Line-of-Business solutions. 

 Hands On 

You will execute the final configuration pieces by integrating your corporate Identity Provider with CIS, establishing system trusts, running user provisioning and exposing content from a live LOB solution into Build Work Zone. You will leave the session with a configured and functional platform ready for activation. 

 

Day 3 ‚Äì Wrap Up and Trouble Shooting 

This is your dedication implementation support session. This day is reserved for you to work directly with our SAP experts in a hands-on, collaborative session. They will help you troubleshoot any specific issues encountered during the previous two days. 

 

Program Deliverables 

  • Completed BTP environment configuration with designated Joule sub-account 
  • Configured identity management and user provisioning workflows 
  • Build Work Zone instance integrated with your SAP applications 
  • Validated prerequisites checklist ensuring deployment readiness 
  • Expert guidance on common implementation challenges and best practices 

 

Who Should Attend 

Technical Architects, Security and Identity Management Specialists, BTP administrators and Architects, and SAP BASIS professionals responsible for implementing and managing SAP‚Äôs AI and integration technologies. 

 

Investment Value 

Accelerate your Joule deployment while avoiding common pitfalls. Our expert-guided approach ensures your team develops competency in managing SAP‚Äôs AI infrastructure, maximising your return on investment.

entry.title: Create a proxy in APIM
entry.content:
Overview and prerequisites

  • Access: SAP BTP subaccount with Integration Suite (CPI) and API Management service enabled.
  • iFlow: A deployed iFlow with an HTTP endpoint (or OData) that you can call.
  • Auth: Credentials or OAuth client for the iFlow‚Äôs endpoint.
  • Portal: API Portal (to build proxies, policies, products) and Developer Portal (for application registration and subscription).



Prepare your iFlow endpoint
‚Ä¢ Locate endpoint: Open your iFlow, go to the sender adapter (e.g., HTTP), and note the runtime URL (host + path).
‚Ä¢ Test direct call: Use a tool like Postman to confirm the iFlow works with its native authentication (Basic or OAuth).
‚Ä¢ Decide security model: Choose how API callers will authenticate. A common pattern is API key at the proxy plus Basic/OAuth from proxy to target.



Create the API proxy

In API Portal

  1. Create API:
    • Name: A clear name (e.g., order-iflow-proxy).
    • Base path: What external consumers will call (e.g., /orders).
    • Target: The iFlow endpoint URL (runtime host + full path).
  2. Resources:
    • Define resource paths: For example, /create, /status/{id}, or keep root if it‚Äôs a single-operation iFlow.
    • Methods: Allow only what you need (e.g., POST for create, GET for status).
  3. Proxy settings:
  • Virtual host: Select your API domain (e.g., default).
  • TLS: Ensure HTTPS is used for both proxy and target.
  • Target auth: Configure Basic or OAuth 2.0 to call CPI from the proxy

 

Add policies
Attach policies to the proxy for authentication, protection, and headers. Below are common, production-safe choices with XML examples you can paste into API Management.

Security and access control

  • Verify API Key: Require an API key from the caller (typically via apikey header or query parameter).

<VerifyAPIKey name="verify-api-key">
<APIKey ref="request.header.apikey"/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

  • Attachment:
        Request flow (PreFlow) before routing to target.
    • Basic authentication to CPI (if applicable):

<AssignMessage name="assign-target-basic-auth">
<Set>
<Headers>
<Header name="Authorization">Basic {base64EncodedUser:Password}</Header>
</Headers>
</Set>
<AssignTo createNew="false">request</AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

 

      • Replace with a Key-Value Map reference or encrypted variable; do not hardcode credentials in production.
    • OAuth 2.0 (client credentials) to CPI (alternative):


      <OAuthV2 name="oauth-to-cpi">
      <Operation>GetAccessToken</Operation>
      <Credentials>
      <Key>client_id_from_kvm</Key>
      <Secret>client_secret_from_kvm</Secret>
      </Credentials>
      <SupportedGrantTypes>
      <GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
      </SupportedGrantTypes>
      <AccessTokenLocation>request.header.Authorization</AccessTokenLocation>
      <AccessTokenPrefix>Bearer</AccessTokenPrefix>
      <GenerateResponse>false</GenerateResponse>
      <ResourceOwnerKey>token_cache_key</ResourceOwnerKey>
      <TokenURL>https://<cpi-host>/oauth/token</TokenURL>
      </OAuthV2>


    • Traffic management and protection

      • Quota: Limit total calls in a time window.
        <Quota name="quota-per-app">
        <Interval>1</Interval>
        <TimeUnit>hour</TimeUnit>
        <Allow>1000</Allow>
        <Distributed>true</Distributed>
        <Identifier ref="verify-api-key.client_id"/>
        </Quota>
      •  Attach in Request PreFlow.
        ‚Ä¢ Spike Arrest: Smooth burst traffic.
        <SpikeArrest name="spike-arrest">
        <Rate>100ps</Rate>
        </SpikeArrest>
      • JSON Threat Protection (if payload is JSON):

        <JSONThreatProtection name="json-threat-protection">
        <MaxObjectDepth>20</MaxObjectDepth>
        <MaxArraySize>10000</MaxArraySize>
        <MaxStringLength>100000</MaxStringLength>
        </JSONThreatProtection>


      • Package into a product

        Products bundle proxies with plans and quotas for controlled access via the Developer Portal.

        1. Create Product:
          • Name: e.g., Orders-API-Product.
          • APIs: Add your order-iflow-proxy.
          • Plans: Define one or more plans with quota and description (e.g., Standard: 1000 calls/hour).
      • Publish Product:
        • Visibility: Set to public or restricted.
        • Attach documentation: Short ‚ÄúGetting Started‚Äù and endpoint specs for developers.

      • Create an application and subscribe

        Applications represent consumers and issue credentials like API keys.

        1. Developer Portal:
          • Register Application: Provide a name, description, and contact.
          • Credentials: The portal generates an API key (client ID).
          • Subscribe: Choose the Orders-API-Product and the plan.
      • Distribute API key:
        • Usage: In client calls, set apikey header (or query param) matching your VerifyAPIKey policy.
        • Rotation: Maintain multiple keys for rotation and revocation.

entry.title: Re: Calculating Standard Deviation or Rolling 3 months in...
entry.content: Yes, in SAP Analytics Cloud you can show rolling three month sales directly by creating a restricted or calculated measure using a time range or moving window without changing the Excel source, and similarly you can calculate and display standard deviation using a calculated measure or variance function in the SAC model or story, so it is not mandatory to modify the Excel file unless you want the logic fixed at source level.

entry.title: Re: Date format in Exporting Table to XLSX in SAC, from B...
entry.content: This happens because in BW live models the date formatting comes directly from the BW query and SAC exports it to Excel as text, so SAC profile date settings do not apply, and Excel cannot automatically convert dd.mm.yyyy text into a date, so the only solutions are to change the date format in the BW query to an ISO compatible format, expose the date as a proper date characteristic, or convert the text to date inside Excel after export, because SAC cannot change date formats for BW live data during XLSX export.

entry.title: Trading Partner Management in SAP Integration Suite: ANSI X12 EDI Integration
entry.content:
Introduction

Trading Partner Management (TPM) in SAP Integration Suite enables enterprises to manage B2B integrations with partners using standards like ANSI X12. It provides a centralized way to define partner profiles, agreements, connectivity, certificates, and mappings, ensuring smooth exchange of EDI documents with SAP backend systems via IDocs.

 

Step 1: Company Profile

  • Define your own organization in TPM.
  • Include identifiers such as DUNS number, GLN, or custom IDs.
  • This profile represents your company in all agreements.

 

Step 2: Partner Profile

  • Create a profile for each trading partner.
  • Capture identifiers (ISA/GS segments in ANSI X12), contact details, and communication channels.
  • Profiles standardize partner metadata for reuse across agreements.

 

Step 3: Agreements

  • Agreements connect your company profile with a partner profile.
  • Define:
    • Transaction sets (ANSI X12 types).
    • Protocols (AS2, SFTP).
    • Certificates for encryption/signing.
  • Agreements govern how messages are exchanged, validated, and acknowledged.

 

Step 4: Connectivity (AS2 & SFTP)

  • AS2: Configure partner endpoint, certificates, MDN settings, and encryption/signature algorithms.
  • SFTP: Define host, port, authentication (password or SSH key), and inbound/outbound directories.
  • Connectivity ensures secure, reliable transport of EDI files.

 

Step 5: Certificates

  • Upload partner public certificates for AS2 encryption/signing.
  • Maintain your own private/public key pairs.
  • Monitor expiry dates to avoid disruptions.

 

Step 6: Mapping

  • Use Integration Advisor or Cloud Integration to map ANSI X12 transaction sets to SAP IDocs.
  • Example: X12 810 (Invoice) ‚Üí INVOIC02 IDoc.
  • Mapping ensures semantic consistency between external EDI formats and SAP internal structures.

 

Common ANSI X12 Transaction Sets and SAP IDoc Types

| ANSI X12 Transaction Set | SAP IDoc Type | Functionality |
|--------------------------|---------------|---------------|
| 850 ‚Äì Purchase Order | ORDERS05 | Customer purchase orders |
| 810 ‚Äì Invoice | INVOIC02 | Supplier invoice processing |
| 856 ‚Äì Ship Notice/Manifest | DESADV05 | Shipment and delivery notifications |
| 820 ‚Äì Payment Order/Remittance Advice | PEXR2002 / REMADV01 | Payment instructions and remittance advice |
| 940 ‚Äì Warehouse Shipping Order | SHPMNT05 | Warehouse shipment details |
| 945 ‚Äì Warehouse Shipping Advice | SHPMNT05 | Confirmation of goods shipped |
| 997 ‚Äì Functional Acknowledgment | CONTRL | Acknowledgment of EDI messages |
| 844 ‚Äì Product Transfer Account Adjustment | GSVERF01 | Adjustments in product accounts |
| 832 ‚Äì Price/Sales Catalog | PRICAT01 | Exchange of product price catalogs |
| 830 ‚Äì Planning Schedule with Release Capability | DELFOR02 | Forecast of deliveries |
| 846 ‚Äì Inventory Inquiry/Advice | INVRPT01 | Inventory reporting |

 

Additional Considerations

  • Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs): Define partner-specific rules for each transaction set.
  • Monitoring: Use TPM dashboards to track message flows, acknowledgments, and errors.
  • Migration: Existing SAP PI/PO EDI scenarios can be migrated to TPM using Integration Advisor.
  • Compliance: Ensure mappings align with SAP Note 104606 for ANSI X12 compatibility.

 

Conclusion

By configuring company profiles, partner profiles, agreements, connectivity, certificates, and mappings, enterprises can seamlessly integrate ANSI X12 EDI flows with SAP IDocs in Integration Suite. TPM reduces onboarding complexity, enforces compliance, and accelerates B2B integration projects.

entry.title: Re: Add Custom BO field to standard report
entry.content:
Dear @KhaingZinTun,

In Public Cloud you generally cannot inject a field that lives only in a Custom Business Object (CBO) into an SAP-delivered standard report standard embedded analytics content. Standard reports are built on SAP-delivered analytical queries / CDS data sources and the supported extensibility is clean-core you can extend the report‚Äôs underlying released data source with custom fields / data source extensions but you don‚Äôt modify SAP standard content to pull in arbitrary custom BO tables

Option A: Best if the field semantically belongs to a standard object. Create a Custom Field on the standard business context

If your CBO field is really an attribute of something standard (Sales Order, Journal Entry, Purchase Order, etc.) the most supported path is:

  1. Create a Custom Fields app in the relevant business context
  2. Enable field usage for Reports / analytics so it becomes available in reporting scenarios

This often makes the field usable in reporting and keeps you upgrade-safe

Option B: Best if the data must stay in the CBO. Build your own report using Custom CDS View + Custom Analytical Queries

Create a custom reporting artifact that combines standard + custom data, instead of altering the standard report:

  1. Create a Custom CDS View based on a released SAP VDM view and where keys allow merge/join it with the CBO-generated table/view

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/b0000072fe994d7b9d5e015adf066059.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/8573b810511948c8a99c0672abc159aa.html

  1. Create a Custom Analytical Queries app on top of that CDS view you can copy an existing query and adapt it and you can add/remove custom fields in the query design
  2. Publish it as a tile/KPI/report for end users

More details below:

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1572')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/33f3a229ecfe438ca6b2053c48b4e1bb.html

This is the standard clean-core way to report on SAP + custom table/BO together

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Mirror, Mirror - Programming a Magic Mirror in Snap!
entry.content:
This article contains videos, PDF materials, and extension ideas for the Magic Mirror project, where photos or live webcam images can be distorted, coloured, or swirled using Snap!‚Äôs built-in graphic effects.

The project is well suited for programming beginners, since it needs very few blocks. With only a couple of programming concepts required, this project can be used from elementary school onward, but from personal experience we know that it also appeals to older learners üòâ.

 

Part 1: Applying Graphic Effects Interactively to a Photo

The basic idea of this first part of the project is to use the set _ effect to _ block to interactively modify a sprite‚Äôs costume. You can either take a photo with the webcam or import an image from your computer into Snap!.

  • Taking a photo with the webcam:
    In Snap! you can access the webcam e.g. from the Costumes tab. Clicking the camera icon opens a window displaying the webcam feed. To capture a webcam costume, click Save. Clicking the Cancel button closes the webcam window.
    If you are using the webcam for the first time from Snap!, you must enable access. Depending on your browser, a pop-up will appear asking you to allow webcam access. If access is denied, the webcam button will be greyed out. In that case, simply reload the page then the browser asks for permission again.
    Click the Costumes tab and then the webcam icon to open the camera (left). The first time, you must grant access (middle ‚Äî screenshot from Google Chrome; the pop-up may vary by browser). Then, by clicking Save, you can capture a photo costume (right). Cancel closes the camera window.

 

  • Importing an image from your computer:
    If no webcam is available or you want to use other images, you can simply import pictures from your computer. Open the file menu and choose Import‚Ä¶. A file browser window will appear that lets you navigate to the desired image.

 

Resources for the first part of the project:

  • This video guides you step by step through the programming process:
    https://youtu.be/ZyGF0VYqm3k 
  • In this activity card, you find a detailed explanation:
    https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/tBkLEtj?rc=10&doi=SAP1267262 
  • This starter project only contains the blocks required for the first and second part of the projects. Starter projects are great when working with younger learners because they reduce cognitive load. However, they also limit the creative options: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Starter 
  • This solution project contains the script for the first part of the project. Fisheye and color were chosen as graphic effects to manipulate the photo. The project is started with the green flag, pressing the space key resets the graphic effects. 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Solution%20-%20Part1 

 

Note for tablet users:

If tablets are used for building or demonstrating the project, one additional step is required. 

On a computer, the mouse x and mouse y positions, which are used to control the effects, can always be accessed. On tablets, this is only possible when an actual touch event happens, meaning a finger or pencil must touch the screen. This however also always counts as a click.

If this click is performed on the photo, the sprite is lifted off the stage and dragged along as the finger moves. You can prevent this by removing the checkmark next to the draggable setting. This ensures that the sprite can only be moved programmatically and no longer by clicking it.

If the draggable box is checked, the sprite can be moved with a mouse click or touch. If the box is unchecked, the sprite can only be moved by the program itself.

 

Part 2: Building a Magic Mirror with Live Video

In the second part of the project, the webcam feed is continuously projected onto a costume. This creates the impression of a live video feed on the mirror sprite. The live image can then be modified again using the graphic effects.

Resources for the second part of the project:

  • This video contains a step by step guide to programming the second part:
    https://youtu.be/42Y95y4RzBs 
  • In this activity card you can find a detailed explanation on how to build the second part of the project:
    https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/bgqjCaa?rc=10&doi=SAP1267261 
  • You can use this solution project to check what you've done:
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Solution%20-%20Part2 

 

Extend the project:

In addition to the built-in graphic effects used in part one and two, you can extend the project with further ideas. The blocks for this are not included in the starter project. Here‚Äôs how you can show or hide blocks:

To hide blocks, right-click on the palette and select "hide blocks‚Ä¶". A dialog window with all the available blocks will open.
In this window, you can select individual blocks to hide by clicking the checkbox next to them or you can right-click inside the dialog box and choose the ‚Äúunused‚Äù option. This is especially useful if you only need the blocks relevant to a specific project: simply build your desired result, then hide all unused blocks. 
After clicking OK, the palette will contain only the blocks you did not choose to hide.

If you want to show hidden blocks again, open the ‚Äúhide blocks‚Ä¶‚Äù dialog once more and remove the checkmark next to the blocks you want to display. If you want to show all blocks, right-click in the dialog window, choose ‚Äúnone‚Äù, and then click OK.
All blocks will then be shown in the palette again. 

 

Distorting the image:

Using the stretch block, you can distort a sprite‚Äôs costume. The stretch block has three inputs: the costume to be stretched, and the stretch or squash values for the x- and y-directions. If both directions are set to 100%, nothing changes, the costume keeps its current proportions. If the x-direction is set to values greater than 100% (e.g., 200, see below), the costume becomes wider. Values below 100% make it narrower.
Values below 100% in the y-direction flatten the costume (e.g., 80, see below), and values above 100% make it taller.

Left: the original ‚ÄúEgg‚Äù costume. Right: the ‚ÄúEgg‚Äù costume stretched to 200% in the x-direction (therefore wider) and squashed to 80% in the y-direction (therefore flatter).

To distort the webcam image for the Magic Mirror, you have to take one additional step. If, instead of stretching the Egg-costume, you directly stretch the video snap costume, the costume will become wider and flatter each time the snapshot is applied. This happens because the object‚Äôs dimensions are stretched to x: 200% and y: 80% every time a new snapshot is put on as a costume - in other words, with each new snapshot the object becomes twice as wide and 0.8 times as tall as before.

The costume is stretched every time the webcam snapshot is applied if it is not reset to its original dimensions beforehand.

Therefore, before switching to the video snap costume, you should always switch back to the original ‚ÄúEgg‚Äù costume. This ensures that the stretch and squash remain consistently at x: 200% and y: 80% of the original size.

Before the video snap is applied and stretched to x: 200% and y: 80%, the sprite switches back to the original ‚ÄúEgg‚Äù costume.

 

Mirroring and duplicating the image:

You can also use the stretch block to mirror a costume in different directions by using negative values for the x- and y-stretch inputs. For example, if the x-direction is set to ‚Äì100%, the costume is mirrored horizontally. If the y-direction is set to ‚Äì100%, it is mirrored vertically.

left: video snap on myself, middle: video snap on myself - mirrored horizontally by stretching to -100% in x-direction, right: video snap on self mirrored vertically by stretching to -100% in y-direction

Mirroring alone isn‚Äôt particularly exciting. It becomes fun when you display mirrored and non-mirrored versions of the image on top of each other.

Create two sprites and move them to the same position. 
The bottom sprite simply keeps the video snap as its costume at all times. The top sprite should also continuously display the webcam image as its costume, but horizontally or vertically mirrored.
Then you can use the ghost (transparency) effect to make the top sprite semi-transparent. Now both versions, the mirrored and the original, are visible at the same time.

Two sprites are displayed on top of each other. Both are continuously setting their costume to video snap of myself. For the top sprite, the costume is stretched to ‚Äì100% in the x-direction, meaning it is horizontally mirrored. In addition, the ghost effect of the top sprite is set to 50, allowing both versions, the original and the horizontally mirrored costume, to be visible at the same time.

You can easily display up to four differently mirrored sprites on top of each other; you just need to adjust the transparency effect for each one accordingly.

 

Rotating the image:

The magic mirror can also rotate. The webcam image is displayed in whatever direction the sprite is currently facing. If the sprite is pointing in direction 90, the image appears ‚Äúupright‚Äù meaning the neck is at the bottom. If you set the direction to 45 degrees, the entire sprite and therefore the video snap is rotated by 45 degrees. The neck now points downwards to the right.

To change the direction continuously, you can use a script that slowly rotates the sprite forever.

left: video snap when the sprite is facing in direction 90. middle: video snap when the sprite is pointing towards 45 degrees. right: script that continuously rotates the sprite by 0.2 degrees.

 

Try out the extensions:

left: distorted mirror image created with the stretch block. middle: two sprites placed on top of each other ‚Äî the top one is semi-transparent (ghost effect 50) and mirrored using the stretch block (x: ‚Äì100, y: 100). right: the sprite turns slowly by 0.2 degrees, therefore the mirror image is facing in different directions.

Test the three extensions in the following solution project:
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Extension 

Press the green flag to start all mirrors. Then press the number key of each mirror to show or hide the corresponding extension.

Key 1 for the distortion mirror
Key 2 for the ‚Äúmirrored‚Äù mirror
Key 3 for the rotating mirror

 

Excursion: Displaying the webcam on other sprites - tips, tricks, and further ideas

The video snap on myself block returns an image that shows the part of the webcam feed that is located behind the sprite executing the block (i.e., "myself"). The image takes the shape of the sprite‚Äôs current costume, regardless of whether the costume was drawn by hand, chosen from the costume library, or imported from your computer.
This also works when the video transparency is set to 100, meaning the webcam feed displayed on the stage is transparent.

The webcam‚Äôs video snap appears on the costume of Alonzo - worn by the sprite running the function.

Sometimes the costume is too small to show the part of the webcam image you want to display on it. In this case, only part of the webcam feed (just one eye instead of the whole face) fits onto the Alonzo costume. Increasing the sprite‚Äôs size, for example, from size 100 to size 250, does not change the portion of the webcam that appears on the sprite. Just like the sprite, the webcam image displayed on it is enlarged, but the cropped segment of the webcam stays the same.

left: the sprite at size 100 with a video snap costume. right: the same sprite at size 250. Everything is scaled up, but the webcam crop stays the same.

If you want to increase the visible area of the webcam feed, you must change the size of the costume, not the sprite itself. You can use the script shown in the following figure. The script that displays the webcam on the sprite can stay as it is. 

top: the sprite at size 100 with its corresponding costume. to the right: the result of the video snap on myself block for this sprite. bottom: the same sprite with an enlarged costume. The script on the left first sets the sprite‚Äôs size to 280. Then it stamps the sprite onto the stage. After that, the sprite‚Äôs size is reset to 100. Subsequently, the stamped marks (pen trails) can be used as a costume. The sprite now has size 100 but with a significantly enlarged costume. This also changes the portion of the webcam image that appears on the costume.top: the sprite at size 100 with its corresponding costume. to the right: the result of the video snap on myself block for this sprite. bottom: the same sprite with an enlarged costume. The script on the left first sets the sprite‚Äôs size to 280. Then it stamps the sprite onto the stage. After that, the sprite‚Äôs size is reset to 100. Subsequently, the stamped marks (pen trails) can be used as a costume. The sprite now has size 100 but with a significantly enlarged costume. This also changes the portion of the webcam image that appears on the costume.

This opens up many additional ideas in the field of media computation with images. For example, how about creating your own graphic effects, such as a negative effect that inverts all colors?
Have you heard of dithering? It‚Äôs a technique among other things used in graphics design that uses only a few colors (in this case, a single shade of green) to create the illusion of greater color depth (here, a ‚Äúgreen-scale‚Äù effect using differently sized green dots).
Or how about generating your own personalized version of Georg Nees‚Äô famous artwork Schotter?

Now it's your turn to get creative or check out further media computation activities  üéº üìú üé•

 

 
These materials are released under a CC-BY-SA 4.0 license by the Snap! team at SAP.

 

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: Re: Securing Enterprise AI on SAP BTP: Zero Trust Authentication with SAP AI Core
entry.content:
Very nice blog!

Could you comment here about the deprecation of SAML on BTP, and whether or not it is preferable to use OIDC-based integration directly instead of SAML?

It is possible to use your corporate IdP in proxy mode from IAS (XSUAA OIDC ‚Üí IAS SAML ‚Üí Corp. IdP), rather than using SAML directly (XSUAA SAML ‚Üí Corp. IdP). While this may seem more complex, it can be simpler, because the trust connection from XSUAA to IAS is very simple to configure using the "Establish Trust" button. Also, the IAS‚ÜíCorp. IdP only needs to be configured once (not once per subaccount). Also, some AI-use cases require XSUAA to use OIDC, not SAML (e.g. Joule for Business in SuccessFactors, S/4, IBP, etc.).

What do you think about continuing to use SAML for new configurations?

entry.title: Re: Two different subtotals for a Rebate condition contract
entry.content:
Hi @HariBoyapati2 

Option 1:
You use 2 sets of rebate conditions. Within customizing you configure that both base values are transferred into the settlement document. This would look like this:

Within the pricing procedure and the condition contract you need 2 rebate conditions. One is using condition REBV as base value, the other is using condition ZRBV as base value.

Option 2: 
You deal with this in the CDS view for the business volume table. Prerequisite: Static logic that is the same for all condition contracts.
I had once the issue that different pricing procedures were involved. These pricing procedures used different subtotals. We used some logic in the CDS view to fix this:

cast( case
when base.kalsm = 'DUMMY' then base.gross_value
when base.kalsm = 'YU1300' then base.bonba
when base.kalsm = 'YU1304' then base.netwr
else base.bonba
end as ZSD_CCS_BONBA ) as bonba,

entry.title: Re: Two different subtotals for a Rebate condition contract
entry.content:
Hi @HariBoyapati2, 

It's not standard to have more than 1 subtotal used per contract based on material type or other. 
Regarding the amount field group split, I would recommend to try it in dev/sandbox environment to see the impact (as any configuration in CCM or other module, you get experience by experimenting and hands on). 

In the meantime, here is the description provided by SAP for Group of Split criteria used for Total amount as per Split:

Controls which split criteria the system applies to determine the amount for the Target Condition Type for Total Amount as per Split Criteria and for the Target Condition Type Total Amount as per Split, Second Side.
Use
The purpose of this group of split criteria is to reduce the number of required customizing objects (profiles for business volume determination and condition contract types) in case that you want to use different split criteria for the determination of the total amount as per split criteria.
The control involves three steps.
‚Ä¢ You define groups of split criteria used for total amounts as per split.
‚Ä¢ In the Amount Fields - Split Criteria dialog structure of a profile for business volume determination you assign different split criteria to a group of split criteria in connection with the target condition types for the total amount as per split criteria on the primary and second side of the settlement document.
‚Ä¢ When you create a new condition contract for a condition contract type that uses the contemplated profile, you specify the split criteria group on the Settlement Data tab page of the condition contract header.
Conclusion: In the settlement run for this condition contract, the system uses those split criteria for the determination of the total amount as per split criteria which you have assigned to the split criteria group specified in the condition contract header.

For your requirement, you could check to capture the correct subtotal directly in 1 fields (e.g. For Material type ABC, KZWI1 = KZWI1, for Material type BCD KZWI1 = KZWI2) in the CDS view used for the profile of business volume. 
However, here are some warnings if you plan to do that: 

  • Logic for subtotal determination should be defined and stable (not per contract created, e.g. customer 1 = logic A and customer 2 = logic B). 
  • You're not posting accrual in the transactional documents, if not the system may calculate Accrual based on Subtotal 1 but for this item it should be based on Subtotal 2. 
  • Audit: You should be able to explain clearly how it's calculated for any Audit control/request. Please check with Audit team prior.

Option 1 provided by @MichaelWerner can be another option but may required some tricks in the pricing procedure + more maintenance in the condition record side within the contract - depend heavily on the requirements.  

Regards, 
Gauthier VICTOR

entry.title: Re: Introducing the Gantt Chart Custom Widget for SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Hello @AEG ,

In your case, the technical IDs are IGCPREXID, IGCPREXID__IGCPLEDDT, IGCPREXID__IGCPLSTDT, and IGCPREXID__IGCRPPHAS. Since you are working only with dates, the Gantt Chart should work without any issues.

The Dataset Parsing Settings mapping should be configured as follows:

  • Event ID: IGCPREXID.id

  • Event Name: IGCPREXID.description

  • Event Description (optional): IGCPREXID.description

  • Event Start Time: IGCPREXID__IGCPLSTDT.id

  • Event End Time: IGCPREXID__IGCPLEDDT.id

  • Parent ID (optional): IGCPREXID__IGCRPPHAS.id

    • Use this only if you need a hierarchical representation and the field references the parent project ID.

    • If a hierarchy is not required, keep the default value Parent_ID.

  • Color of Event Bar (optional): Color

    • Leave this as the default value, since there is no color information in your model.

@andreasja_schneider, many thanks for your inputs.

entry.title: Re: Multiple payment method for one open AP
entry.content:
Good day @ChinYeeChia 

Thank you for your question

In the public cloud one payment document can only have one payment method. That means in your case you cannot clear 30,000 by bank transfer and 70,000 by BoE within the same clearing transaction. So, the best practice is for you to use two separate payment documents, each with its own payment method, both clearing the same invoice. See below link on supplier invoice creation: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/01060a2e758f4e8a9d4a7cf07b0ce323.html?locale=en-US and posting General Journal Entries: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/950f8054747b053de10000000a441470.html?locale=en-US

My recommendation on how to pay one invoice with bank transfer & BoE, is to:

  • Post a partial 30,000 USD payment with the ‚Äúbank transfer‚Äù method, and
  • Clear the remaining 70,000 USD with a BoE document by using the BoE Process.

Both will ensure you fully clear the same supplier invoice, and each carries its own payment method.

Below is a step-by-step approach you may consider:

Step 1: In your manual payment app, enter your bank account, company code, currency and payment method for the bank transfer.

Then select the supplier and then your open invoice of 100,000 USD. Enter 30,000 USD payment amount and post document

This will partially clear the invoice with the bank transfer payment method. The remaining open amount on the invoice is now 70,000 USD.

Step 2: Use your BoE process/app (this will depend on the country you have activated or your BoE scope) to create a bill of Exchange and reference the same supplier invoice.

  • Reference the vendor and the particular invoice
  • Enter 70,000 USD as the amount to be cleared
  • Choose BoE as payment method and post the BoE document

This will clear the remaining 70,000 UD on the invoice. You will then have both amounts split accordingly.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Fieldglass Sandbox Environment Refresh: 5 Tips for Success
entry.content:
Refreshing your sandbox environment with current production data keeps testing, troubleshooting, and training accurate and realistic. But there are important considerations and data privacy safeguards you need to know before scheduling a refresh. Here are 5 tips to help ensure your sandbox environment refreshes are smooth, timely, and successful.

1. Know Your Refresh Limits

Your sandbox edition determines how many refreshes you can request each year and the maximum data slice you can include in each refresh.

 

Edition

Annual Refresh Limit per Sandbox

Maximum Data Slice

Base Edition

Up to 2 refreshes annually

6 months of Production data (can be less)

Premium Edition

Up to 4 refreshes annually

1 year of Production data

(can be less)

Learn more about base and premium sandbox environments on the SAP Help Portal.

2. Provide 30 Days‚Äô Notice

All production data refresh requests must be scheduled via SAP for Me at least 30 days in advance of your desired refresh date. This lead time ensures resources are available and helps avoid delays to your project or testing cycles.

3. Plan Your Timing Strategically

With limited annual refreshes, align them with your highest priorities, such as:

  • Before major product releases or integration testing
  • Ahead of critical training sessions
  • After significant business process changes or migrations

4. Follow Post-Refresh Best Practices

Once the environment refresh is complete:

  • Validate critical data, configurations, and integrations
  • Reapply sandbox-only settings (for example, test user roles, custom scripts)
  • Notify your team when the environment is ready for use

5. Understand Data Anonymization

To protect personal and confidential information, certain PII fields are anonymized during every sandbox refresh, including in customer-paid sandboxes. This includes the following fields:

  • Email
  • Address
  • Phone number
  • LinkedIn profile URL
  • Resume name
  • Ariba Network ID (ANID) for Supplier and Buyer

It is also important to note, the following PII fields are not anonymized in the sandbox environments, including customer-paid sandboxes, by default. However, you can request SAP Fieldglass Support to anonymize these fields by submitting a case via SAP for Me or the SAP Fieldglass Help Center:

  • First Name
  • Last Name
  • Display Name
  • Company Name
  • Company Street Address

Make sure to check out the SAP Help Portal to learn more about data security.

In summary, using these quick reminders will help you get the most out of your sandbox refreshes. With thoughtful scheduling and clear post-refresh checks, you can ensure your sandbox is accurate, secure, and ready to support your most critical initiatives without wasting any time.

Don‚Äôt forget to explore the SAP Help Portal for more information on the SAP Fieldglass Sandbox Environment Landscape.

entry.title: SAC Story Bookmark. Unable to save a bookmark.
entry.content:
Issue with bookmarks. Unable to save bookmark error message. 
In log (Developer Tools) a message appears: We can‚Äôt have another bookmark with the name ‚Ä¶ in this target resource. 

There are no bookmarks in the story self however. 

Reason was in the Bookmarks version which was changed, what caused all old bookmarks to be invalidated, but not deleted. Means the bookmarks are still in the background, but not visible for the user in the Story self.

Go to Story \ Bookmarks, choose Invalid bookmarks and delete.

entry.title: Re: QR- Bill Process from SD Invoice to FI Clearing via C...
entry.content:
Good day @FelixSchwarzIGB 

Thank you for your question

Swiss QR Bill printing and automatic clearing are standard capabilities in the public cloud but they depend on the following being correct at the same time:

  1. The invoice must carry a usable payment reference for the QR Bill process which is typically the payment reference field KIDNO on the customer line item.
  2. The CAMT file must contain that same reference in the remittance or structured reference so the interpretation and search logic can find the open item.

To answer your question regarding clearing logic:

Answer on Storage: Yes, you should expect the full QR reference to be available for clearing search and the standard place is the payment reference on the customer open item. SAP does support configuring search logic that can use other references but if KIDNO is empty that will usually reduce the results rate and you will have more manual work. See links below for more insights:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/ee9ee0ca4c3942068ea584d2f929b5b1/61752f6774614b0f8c637d9a305ab798.html?locale=en-US&version=2508.00

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/bb9f1469daf04bd894ab2167f8132a1a/13c22c58f5809344e10000000a4450e5.html?locale=en-US

If you need to influence how the QR Bill reference is generated or adjusted, you should use the released QR Bill extensibility option for Switzerland. This explains how you can change the payment reference number KIDNO as part of the QR Bill processing. See link below for further details:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/6833660c7722498fb41584b098420f89/32d90e4b974742a69316c573e8cd3cb5.html?locale=en-US

Answer on FI document not showing QR reference in KIDNO: There could be a few reasons for that, such as:

  1. The process you use to create invoice is not actually triggering the creation logic for the QR Bill reference.
  2. You are looking at a UI that, by default does not display the field, while the value may still exist on the customer line item.
  3. The reference might ben generated for output but the QR Bill configuration is not aligned to your invoice scenario.

I suggest as a next step to validate it on the customer line item in the Journal entry and not only on the printed form preview.

Answer on Dunning QR reference: Generally, SAP supports dunning notices that include QR Bill data. The system generates the reference on the dunning noticed and it is used to match incoming payments back to the relevant open items by the pre-configured logic without you being required to store that dunning reference on every original FI document line. In public cloud you typically validate this through the dunning apps and the bank statement processing results rather than you carrying out a table inspection. See the following reference for more insights: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/6833660c7722498fb41584b098420f89/591a0ee25e2941308fe03fd90842e072.html?locale=en-US

Answer on CAMT.053 and CAMT.054: Yes, you do not need by default both of them. One format is sufficient if it contains the needed reference information and your process timing is met. Typically, CAMT.053 is used for end of day statements while CAMT.054 is for intraday or detailed notifications. In public cloud bank statement processing supports you to import CAMT formats through the Manage Incoming Payment Files process. See below link for more insights: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/6833660c7722498fb41584b098420f89/ee71eb0cd10b4843968ea046701e3b7c.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/doc/ce01d82756b947a1a043a5d5a3204226/2402.503/de-DE/WN_CE2402.3_DE.pdf

In summary, for you to enable reliable automatic clearing for Swiss QR invoices in the public cloud, your invoice must carry a usable payment reference, which is the KIDNO and your CAMT.053 or CAMT.054 entry must contain the same QR reference in the remittance or structured reference. The fact that the bank reports credits on the main CHF account statement can be acceptable but only if the CAMT entry includes the QR reference so Switzerland interpretation and search priorities can match the open item.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP WM- SAP creating TOs with incorrect batch quantity
entry.content:
Hello! I'm assisting client with SAP WM issue in ECC 6.0.   There is a program in place for warehouse users to generate a suggested batch pick list for outbound deliveries.  The pick list data corresponds to a Transfer Order created by the program in the background and is based on the materials and quantities from the  sales order/delivery and the suggested batches/bins are based on our SPRO configuration for the stock removal strategy. All pretty standard stuff. 

The problem is the pick list and related transfer order recently started suggesting random partial quantities of batches  instead of full quantities of batches. For example: Delivery requires 4,000 pcs of material 1A, and a full quantity batch of material 1A is 2,000 pcs. Instead of suggesting two 2,000 pcs full batches of material 1A, the TO  may create for 1,000 pcs from four different full batches of material 1A.   The customer requirement is to ship the full amount of each batch, so this is a problem.

When debugging with team dev, he says the decision to pick partial quantities is coming from the standard SAP programming, not the Z program. We have a small team, and no one states they've made any changes recently to cause this.  I've searched through the Logistics Execution configuration and cant find the problem, which is only occurring in production environment, not in QA or development, as we have tried to reproduce many times and cannot. The entire qty on each batch is created at the same time, so it isn't a FIFO matter.  Has anyone encountered this issue before? What are we overlooking in config that should be changed/investigated?

entry.title: Re: S4 Public Cloud Custom RF verification
entry.content:
Good day @sshetty08 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, yes, the public cloud offers this possibility but only within the standard extensibility and configuration option that is released for Warehouse Management and barcode scanning.

  • You can configure your system to parse barcodes and derive business fields such as product, batch, HU or serial from them by using barcode parsing configuration and GS1 based standards. See the following reference for more insights: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/dcc5840b808f4de989a93a02ece18e1b.html?locale=en-US
  • You can also enforce scanning and verification behaviour on RF screens by using verification profiles and their determination.  See KBA 3351672 for more details.

However, the public cloud does not allow you to implement a custom ABAP user exit style logic on RF field level except there is a released BAdI or extension point for it by SAP.

So, for your example where supplier barcode contains multiple embedded fields, not only product, i suggest you:

  • First try to solve it with barcode parsing rules.
  • Alternatively, you can then apply RF verification profiles to enforce that the decoded value is checked during the RF process.

This blog contains some useful insights: Extensibility Approaches in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Deletion of Scope Items
entry.content:
Hi!

After the scope items are selected and the Define Scope activity is completed, it is not possible to delete them from the workspace.

However, as long as the workspace has not been deployed to the Target System, you still have the option to delete the workspace and recreate it without selecting the undesired scope items.

For more details, please refer to the KBA 3255117 - Not possible to delete scope items (scenarios) after activating it - SAP for Me

You can find instructions on how to delete a workspace in Working with Workspaces | SAP Help Portal.

Best regards,

entry.title: SAP Developer News December 18th, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION

Joule Studio Agent Builder Released 

  • Joule Studio Documentation: https://help.sap.com/docs/Joule_Studio?locale=en-US 
  • Webinars on ‚ÄúSAP TechEd Takeaways: Unlocking Agentic AI with Joule Studio in SAP Build‚Äù: https://event.on24.com/eventRegistration/EventLobbyServlet?target=reg20.jsp&eventid=5132226&sessionid=1&key=68EAF8F96311AF0C06B557E4B6FAADAD&groupId=6438260&partnerref=sapcom&sourcepage=register 
  • Maria on ‚ÄúUnlocking SAP BTP‚Äù Podcast: https://pod.link/990578446/episode/ODE0OGVkZGMtMWQyNy00ZDVlLTgxMDYtODI0YjYyZWY4NTYz?view=apps&sort=popularity (podcast) and https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7-DWT6qd15I(YouTube) 
  • Customer use case for building agent for procurement process: https://www.sap.com/assetdetail/2025/12/ecad099c-317f-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html 
  • Setting Up Joule Studio for All Partner Flows and Entitlement Levels (blog): https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/setting-up-joule-studio-for-all-partner-flows-and-entitlement-levels/ba-p/14282498\ 
  • Setting Up Joule Studio for All Customer Flows and Entitlement Levels (blog): https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/setting-up-joule-studio-for-all-customer-flows-and-entitlement-levels/ba-p/14240537 

ABAP Holiday Calendar 2025 

  • LinkedIn Post https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/abap-holiday-calendar-2025-sonja-li%25C3%25A9nard-wampe/  

GenAI Hub now officially LLM provider for LiteLLM 

  • Documentation: https://sap-contributions.github.io/litellm-agentic-examples/ 
  • Devtoberfest Session on LiteLLM: https://community.sap.com/t5/devtoberfest/connect-to-generative-ai-hub-with-litellm-and-build-ai-agents-with-crewai/ev-p/14217011 

New release 1.18 of the Terraform Provider for SAP BTP 

  • Release info https://github.com/SAP/terraform-provider-btp/releases  
  • BTP CLI and APIs CodeJam section on extracting the CF API endpoint value https://github.com/SAP-samples/cloud-btp-cli-api-codejam/blob/main/exercises/05-core-services-api-prep/README.md#extracting-the-api-endpoint-value  

CAP Enterprise Analytics 

  • NPM Package Details: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@sap/cds-analytics 

SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtime trial restrictions lifted 

  • Carolin‚Äôs blog post, updated https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/update-btp-trial-update-cf-runtime-availability/ba-p/14247240  

Devtoberfest Winners Interview - Kanika Chhabra 

 

CHAPTER TITLES  

0:00 Intro 

0:10 Joule Studio Agent Builder Released 

2:42 ABAP Holiday Calendar 2025 

2:58 GenAI Hub now officialy LLM provider for LiteLLM 

4:24 New release 1.18 of the Terraform Provider for SAP BTP 

5:18 CAP Enterprise Analytics 

6:02 SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtime trial restrictions lifted 

6:44 Devtoberfest Winners Interview - Kanika Chhabra 

 

TRANSCRIPTION

[Intro] This is the SAP Developer News for December 18th, 2025.

[Daniel] Tomorrow, Joule Studio is expected to release the much-anticipated Agent Builder, where you can create agents for yourself without coding in order to extend Joule. You provide the instructions on the context, as well as a set of skills and other tools, and the agent will analyze, plan, and execute the appropriate actions all by itself. You can specify the LLM you want to use, how much thinking you want the agent to do, as well as several more settings. Included are several features even the beta participants did not get to see, including Vibe coding, where you can use prompts to build your agent step-by-step. You can connect to an MCP server and bring those skills into your agent. And you can create sub-agents that can be called by your main agent. Maria Kondratyeva, a senior product manager who has been working tirelessly to get this release out the door before Christmas, says that you will incur no additional unit cost through the end of January when you deploy and test your new agents. I will leave a set of links to materials about Joule Studio and the Agent Builder, including documentation, webinars, and Maria's recent appearance on the very popular Unlocking SAP BTP podpass. That's a really nice jingle. All the links are in the description. Now that Joule Studio is complete with the Agent Builder and the Skill Builder, I assume now more than ever you'll want to install Joule Studio and get started. Lucky for you, Product Management, specifically Maria and Charin, have produced two blogs on how to set up Joule Studio, one specifically for partners and one specifically for customers. It will show you the SKUs you need for build and Joule. It'll show you the boosters, the formations, the security setup, the roles, and everything that you need for whatever landscape you're using, and whether or not you've already installed Joule Studio or Joule or Process Automation. Links to both of those blogs are also in the description.

[Shilpa] Christmas is around the corner, and the SAP ABAP team brings you ABAP holiday calendar 2025. Check out the LinkedIn post by Sonia, where she highlights the key achievements in the area of ABAP in this year.

[Nora] I have some really cool news for all the SAP AI developers out there. It's basically an early Christmas gift because my friend from development just reached out to me, they told me that generative AI hub is now an official large language model provider for light LLM. Now what is light LLM? Light LLM is an open source library that basically unifies all the different API calls to the different large language model providers. So if it's compatible now with generative AI hub, that means that you can use all the models that we partner with. You can use generative AI hub and light LLM and then all the cool agent development kits, for example, that are compatible with light LLM, and that is really cool because the list is endless. I have those tier because I can't remember everything. So there's LandGraph, Crew AI, Pydantic AI, Google Agent Development Kit, so ADK, OpenAI ADK, AWS TransAgents, Lama Index, Microsoft Agents, and that's not even the whole list. It goes on and on and on. So make sure you check out the documentation that is linked in the show notes wherever they appear. And then also check out the Devtoberfest session with my colleague Karim, who also linked a GitHub repository, where he shows how you can build your own AI agents with generative AI Hub, LightLLM and Crew AI. And yeah, happy coding over the holidays. Happy holidays and happy coding.

[DJ] The team behind the Terraform provider for SAP BTP has an early holiday season present for us. A new version, 1.18, has just landed, bringing fixes, improvements, and new features. Here are just three of the highlights. So first, resources and data sources for destinations are now available. MTLS authentication for service brokers is now supported and there are also some new functions for extracting information from environment instance labels, if you know you know. Check out the full release details for these and more features. By the way, there's already a patch version 1.18.1 which you should use. Links in the description.

[Tom] This month we see a great new CAP add-in in the form of the SAP enterprise analytics add-in. This cool new little feature brings to CAP the support for INA services or information access. These are particularly useful when you want to consume a service from the SAP Analytics Cloud, particularly if you have a calculation view. It's very easy to use: drop in the record referred to module, NPN module, and then simply add some annotations to your data model. It's that simple to now add INA services. So if you're interested in that functionality, be sure to check it out today.

[DJ] A few weeks back, we had a news item on access being temporarily restricted for SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtimes in the trial environment. Just a few days ago, the SAP BTP trial product team announced that these restrictions have been lifted again and Cloud Foundry runtimes are now fully available again in trial. That's great news and another early holiday season present for us. A link to Carolyn's original blog post, which now has an update with these details, is in the description.

[Kanika Chhabra] 'm so happy to have one of our winners from Devtoberfest. So give me this car. I did happy day possible. Oh yeah, she take away it out of that. High ah, so many like that. I did not have a lot of tech background but I was able to do the exercises and MPK, so it was really intuitive and everything was really well developed. So I didn't need to have a lot of background knowledge because one cannot know everything about everything. So it was really very made. That's what's really was raised. And now you are here in Berlin, One TechEd. So what did you like most or what you're looking for to get out of here? So I just got a little interested in SAP Build and I found out all the SAP Build hands-on workshops here, and that really helped me. So I do not have a prior experience on that but I started from scratch here working on the SAP Build and I was actually able to learn a lot and now I have a certification made on SAP BuilderXS. Yeah, so I have like exciting about that. Very impressive. Thank you so much.

entry.title: Brazil as One of the Leading Hubs for Artificial Intelligence (2024‚Äì2025)
entry.content:
Over the past two years, Brazil has established itself as one of the main Artificial Intelligence (AI) hubs globally, standing out for its combination of public investments, expanding business ecosystem, and regulatory progress. Traditionally a leader in innovation and technology in Latin America, Brazil is now attracting international attention by accelerating the adoption of AI across strategic sectors such as finance, energy, agribusiness, and public services.

In 2024, the Brazilian government launched the Brazilian Artificial Intelligence Plan (PBIA) 2024‚Äì2028, a program with an estimated investment of R$ 23 billion dedicated to AI research, development, and infrastructure. The plan aims to strengthen technological sovereignty, foster innovation through universities, and support companies in applying AI to practical use cases, particularly in areas of public interest.

The Main pillars of the PBIA 2024‚Äì2028 are:

  • Expansion of AI research and innovation centers;
  • Tax incentives for startups and public‚Äìprivate partnerships;
  • Training and qualification of AI professionals;
  • Implementation of AI in public services (health, security, education).

This initiative positions Brazil as a regional leader in AI policy, ahead of countries like Mexico, Chile, and Argentina.

Brazil‚Äôs private sector is undergoing a phase of rapid AI adoption. By 2025, a national survey identified 396 Brazilian AI companies focused on marketing applications, reflecting diversification across generative AI, automation, analytics, and digital services.

According to a Bain & Company (2025) study, 67% of Brazilian companies now consider AI a strategic priority, a major leap from 2024, when only about 12% had active projects. This demonstrates the transition from experimental use to mature, production-level adoption.

Brazil received international investments and technological infrastructure. That's why Brazil‚Äôs consolidation as an AI hub also stems from the confidence of major global players. In September 2024, Microsoft announced a US$ 2.7 billion investment in cloud and AI infrastructure in Brazil, one of the largest technology investments in Latin American history. In 2025, Eletrobras partnered with C3 AI to modernize Brazil‚Äôs power grid using AI and machine learning, highlighting the industrial applications of advanced technologies.

These moves strengthen Brazil‚Äôs position as a regional hub for data and high-performance computing, essential for scaling generative AI and automation initiatives.

Despite major progress, Brazil still faces structural challenges. A SAP Brazil (March 2025) survey revealed that:

  • 29% of companies lack clarity on how to integrate AI into their business systems;
  • 28% cite a shortage of skilled professionals as the main obstacle.

On the regulatory front, Brazil has emerged as a key player. In 2024, the National Data Protection Authority (ANPD) suspended Meta Platforms‚Äô privacy policy, which used Brazilians‚Äô personal data to train generative AI models. This decision marked an important milestone in ethical governance and digital sovereignty, aligning Brazil with European-style data protection principles.

The main sectors driving AI growth in Brazil include:

  • Finance and digital payments: automation and predictive analytics;
  • Energy: smart grids and real-time system optimization;
  • Agribusiness: crop forecasting and climate analytics;
  • Healthcare: assisted diagnostics and telemedicine;
  • Public administration: chatbots and natural language processing for citizen services.

These industries attract investments from both large corporations and local startups, making Brazil a fertile ground for experimentation and innovation.

About the Outlook for 2025 and Beyond the trends indicate continued expansion of generative AI and process automation in Brazilian companies. By the end of 2025, it is expected that:

  • Over 60% of corporate AI solutions in Brazil will involve generative models;
  • The country will consolidate international research and training partnerships;
  • The General Artificial Intelligence Law (under discussion in Congress) will advance the national governance framework.

With growing public and private investments, Brazil is on track to become a Latin American reference in AI innovation and ethics, combining economic growth with responsible technological governance.

The 2024‚Äì2025 period marks a strategic turning point for AI in Brazil, shifting from an emerging topic to a core pillar of industrial and business competitiveness. The alignment between government vision, international investments, and technological maturity positions Brazil as one of the leading AI hubs in the Southern Hemisphere, with the potential to export technology, talent, and regulatory best practices.

SAP Financial Apps use AI-powered applications for SAP Finance, focused on enhancing financial visibility and decision-making. We can use leverages data from Supply Chain, Sales, Treasury, Accounts Receivable, Accounts Payable, and real-time Bank Balances to deliver accurate forecasting and scenario simulation, ensuring that financial teams have a clear, data-driven view of their company‚Äôs liquidity at any time.

Is your company already exploring AI implementation projects? In which sectors or business processes are you seeing the greatest potential for transformation?

entry.title: CAP - Hide/Show standard Create/Edit Buttons based on Roles
entry.content:
I have an list report / object page app where only one role has access to the Create/Edit/Delete buttons, other roles have read-only access. Authorisations have been defined in my annotations, however the Create/Edit/Delete buttons still show up in the app UI (pressing on them gives a Forbidden error).

annotate MyService.MyEntity with @(restrict: [
    {
        grant: 'READ',
        to   : ['LimitedRole']
    },
]);

Instead I would prefer to hide/disable those buttons for users with the read only roles. I tried following the example mentioned in the documentation here: https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/advanced/fiori#use-roles-to-toggle-visibility-of-ui-elements

However, I've found some options work and some do not. In terms of disabling buttons, I found that only the DeleteRestrictions has any effect:

annotate MyService.MyEntity with @(Capabilities: {
    // Disable Standard Buttons for non-admin roles (only works for Delete, no effect for Create and Edit)
    InsertRestrictions: {Insertable: {$edmJson: {$Path: '/MyService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
    UpdateRestrictions: {Updatable: {$edmJson: {$Path: '/MyService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
    DeleteRestrictions: {Deletable: {$edmJson: {$Path: '/MyService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
});

In terms of hiding the standard buttons, this is a bit better as it works for both Edit and Delete, however it also does not effect the Create button.

annotate MyService.MyEntity with @(Capabilities: {
    // Hide Standard Buttons for non-admin roles (only works for Edit and Delete, no effect for Create)
    UI.CreateHidden: {$edmJson: {$Not: {$Path: '/CatalogService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
    UI.UpdateHidden: {$edmJson: {$Not: {$Path: '/CatalogService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
    UI.DeleteHidden: {$edmJson: {$Not: {$Path: '/CatalogService.EntityContainer/Configuration/isAdmin'}}},
});

 The strange thing to me is that since it works for Edit and Delete it shows that the path is correct and the isAdmin logic is also working correctly (console.log in the service handler also confirms this). If I hardcode UI.CreateHidden to true or 

InsertRestrictions:{Insertable to false, then both have the desired effect that I'm after.
 
So to me I've confirmed that the properties are correct for what I want to achieve (by hardcoding to true/false and testing), and the dynamic logic is correct in that is works partially for Edit and Delete. However, both annotations for the Create button only seem to work with a hardcoded true or false. Is there something else I'm missing?

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Äì Dunning Notice Email to Cu...
entry.content:
Good day @Praveen06 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, your expectation is reasonable but there is an important distinction in the Output Management within the public cloud:

  • The business receiver role for the output item (typically the customer role for dunning) is selected by the receiver determination.
  • One or more email addresses for that output item is then derived by the email recipient determination. While the system supports multiple recipients, getting a list of contact persons usually requires the released enhancement option.

1. On your question about ‚ÄúIs it standard that Contact Person is not selectable in Receiver Role": The answer is yes. The reason is, in the dunning output scenario, the Receiver role list is limited to the roles SAP uses as business receivers for the output item. The system does not typically treat contact persons as separate receiver rile in this step. Instead, the system handles thema as an additional email recipient. See reference for more insights: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/e616af23d2b947fbb275deb759b7090b.html?locale=en-US

2. On your question about your configuration being sufficient to email the customer and all dunning contact person: It is sufficient to email the customer email, if the customer email is available in the context and you map it in the Email Recipient step. So, if your requirement is to send to all contact persons marked as dunning recipient, then the approach is typically to:

  • Keep your Email Recipient mapping for the customer and
  • Add additional recipients through the released BAdI for additional email recipients.

--> See KBA 2976132 for more details.

3. Regarding the additional prerequisite for multiple contact person emails: I suggest you use the released enhancement option BAdI (APOC_ADD_EMAIL_RECIPIENTS). See more details here: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/c5b0dbca5f3548aba2979de7a3f380e4.html?locale=en-US & https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/98c23e90e0864287a770eb9c6358b26c.html?locale=en-US . This BAdI returns multiple recipients for one output item. For dunning specifically, the KBA 3517737 provides details on setup.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Changes to Android Offline Learning Offline Coming in February
entry.content:
If your organization uses the Learning ‚Äúoffline content‚Äù feature in the SuccessFactors native Android mobile app, please read on.

What‚Äôs Changing

With the February 2026 app update (v16.1.0), we‚Äôll be making foundational changes which affect the on-device database that manages the learner‚Äôs downloaded content, offline learning progress, and LMS sync. This has two implications for users who may have content or learning progress saved to their devices at the time the mobile app update is installed.

First, technical limitations prevent content that's currently downloaded to devices from being migrated to the new database. So, any downloaded content will unfortunately be removed from users' devices as part of the app update, and will need to be re-downloaded after the new version of the app has been installed and they‚Äôre online.

Equally important, any offline learning progress saved to devices that has not already been synced with LMS, will also not be migrated to the new database. So, users should make sure to sync any offline progress prior to February 16, when the v16.1.0 update will be released to the Play Store and the Tencent store.

 

What Users Should Do

If your organization hasn‚Äôt enabled downloadable learning content or your users aren‚Äôt actively using offline content on the SuccessFactors native Android app, no action is needed.

For affected users, we recommend syncing learning progress just prior to the release of the app update on February 16, and not completing any further offline learning activities until the new version has been successfully installed on the device.

Syncing offline progress is easy- users only need to open the SuccessFactors app while online, and LMS sync automatically runs in the background. Users will see a success message on-screen once the sync has been completed, which typically takes no more than a few seconds.

If you have users who have been working offline but will be unable to sync their progress prior to the app update, we recommend that app auto-updates be temporarily disabled in their device's operating system settings. When the user is able to come back online, they should launch the SuccessFactors app first, to sync learning progress. Then, after successful sync, they can restore the app store auto-update setting to allow version 16.1.0 to be installed, or manually initiate the update.

Other mobile learning features are not affected by this change, and users can continue to use the apps normally before and after we release the update. Likewise, offline learning in the SuccessFactors iOS app and the dedicated Validated Learning apps are not impacted by this change. Thanks for reading, and please ask any questions in the comments.

 

Related Information

Mobile and Offline Learning

Create Mobile and Offline Learning Content

entry.title: Re: Customer Return(A2X) API and In-House Repair API Comb...
entry.content:
Hello @srinivasareddybhimanadham 

Thank you for your question

  1. Regarding your question on an API availability: No, not as a standard released API
  2. On your question about relationship information: Yes, the relationships exist as mentioned above
  3. Regarding the released CDS views availability: No, there is no single none that delivers your intent.

Below is my explanation

In summary, the public cloud does not provide single standard API that combines Customer Return (A2X) and In House Repair into one object model. There are only process relationships between the two business areas and separate API for each. See following references for more insights:

In House Repair: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/6d57d4ab71e5408581e2018320a0ce49/40347a9ad1b54a4b931ea07b54faa42d.html?locale=en-US

Customer Returns: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/588780cab2774a7ab9fffca3a7f919fe/807fa67fc625453bad4756e4832f42f5.html?locale=en-US

See a similar community question: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/relationship-between-in-house-repair-3xk-and-customer-returns-bkp/qaq-p/12656573

I suggest you

  • Use the released APIs (Customer Return A2X and In House Repair side by side.
  • Use the standard process integration between return and repair. This Blog provides some insights: In-House Repair in S/4HANA Service - Start with an Overview
  • You may consider using Service Order APIs as the linking object when needed. See the following reference for more details: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/6d57d4ab71e5408581e2018320a0ce49/6e59e3179c924b4f8f8df9bf2569aa9d.html?locale=en-US

 

Best regards

Chris

I've searched but could not find any official documentation or for connecting these specific apps (EPD to SBPA) across different subaccounts. Most guides assume a single-subaccount setup where the SAP Booster handles the wiring automatically.

entry.title: Re: Error When Generating DOC via ‚ÄúRun Statutory Reports‚Äù...
entry.content:
Good day @Yaya_AB 

Thank you for your question

The fact that you performed the same process /Test in your test system without errors but the client gets the Generation failed error could be based on a few factors. I suggest you check if:

  • There are missing business catalog or lack of authorisation for report run objects on your client‚Äôs side. The reason is, the functionality depends on both tenant and user. Which often differs between Test and Prod. See KBA 3587016 for more insights.
  • The statutory reporting configuration in the prod tenant is complete. For example, reporting entity, assignments or your FEC setup might be inconsistent. See reference below for more details:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/33b132c0121c41f3b412258173d76b0d/358fb318c9cc4ceb8299135ec2c03a6f.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/33b132c0121c41f3b412258173d76b0d/e937bec0b2b94d628c71b7bb95b91aa5.html?locale=en-US

  • The error is generated because of data volume or your runtime issue which might lead to a backend error. See KBA 3575645 for some instances.
  • The run technically created something but the file it produced cannot be downloaded or is empty.

I suggest you capture the run log and the background job log first, then you validate statutory reporting setup and user catalogs in your client‚Äôs productive system.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Archiving Custom Database Tables in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
I assume you want to use the archiving framework provided by SAP.
First you should define whether you want to archive for volume management (without ILM) or rather data destruction (with ILM) based on retention period and if the released API covers your requirements. According to the documentation, both can be used for custom tables. Have you tried the example implementations?
Both variants eventually use the Archive Development Kit (ADK) API to store the archive file in the storage system - compressed as binary data. You cannot decide the format. You need ABAP Logic to deserialize the binary data. There is no option to store it in a human readable, structured format.
As far as I know, the REST API of DMS does not support reading stored files with offset (length). Therefore I would not recommend using it because ADK likes to read in small packages. For SAP Archiving objects, the storage system is now SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake Files (HDLF). Therefore I would recommend HDLF as the storage system for your custom archive objects.
In the volume management variant you need to implement a storage manager. This is the interface for ADK to the storage system. In your custom storage manager implementation you can call any storage system you like.
Unfortunately, we don't have an example implementation of a custom storage manager for HDLF but we are working on it. Basically you call the REST API of the storage system and send the archive file which is handed over by ADK to the storage manager.
